feedback.Physical object: Included — A tangible unit composed of housings, chambers, and filter media.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Included — Designed and manufactured by humans for a clear technical function.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: Excluded — May mimic natural filtering effects, but not conceptually modeled on biology.
feedback.Fixed/static: Included — Typically remains stationary during use, whether installed or gravity-fed.
feedback.Structural: Included — Geometry and layering of materials directly determine filtration performance.
feedback.Perceptible: Included — User-visible, manually operated or replaceable.
feedback.Material form: Included — Constructed from durable solid-state materials.
feedback.Passive: Included — Most operate without active sensors, software, or external power.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Included — Built specifically to remove unwanted substances from water.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Included — Produces filtered water as output.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: Excluded — Operates mechanically, not by logical control.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: Included — Filters accumulate contaminants over time.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Excluded — Generally no interactive UI or active feedback.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Included — Can be integrated with plumbing or broader water systems.
feedback.Autonomous in function: Included — Operates on its own during fluid flow; user not required to intervene mid-process.
feedback.System-critical: Excluded — May be important, but not semantically critical for broader system operation.
feedback.Communicative: Excluded — No symbolic or signal-based communication.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: Excluded — Behavior arises from physical dynamics, not encoded logic.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Excluded — Internal construction does not imply modular semantic structure.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Excluded — Does not guide user decisions or social behavior.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Excluded — No reflection or internal representation of function.
feedback.Temporal: Included — Filter degradation and replacement cycles are time-dependent.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Excluded — Purpose and behavior do not change across social contexts.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Excluded — Grounded in universal physical function.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Excluded — Standards may exist, but not semantically defined by social systems.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Excluded — Not associated with personal or group roles.
feedback.Regulated / governed: Excluded — Regulation may apply externally but does not define the device's nature.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Excluded — Use may be taught, but this is not a core semantic trait.
feedback.Visible: Included — Deliberately accessible and often user-facing for replacement or monitoring.
feedback.Context-sensitive: Excluded — Identity and behavior remain stable across different uses.
feedback.Widely known: Included — Commonly recognized and used in domestic and public contexts.

encoding_notes: This encoding treats the water filtration unit as a structurally fixed, passive physical mechanism with autonomous function and no symbolic or computational capacity. It includes time-dependence and broad recognizability while excluding overextensions into abstract or interactive domains.
